Absolutely stunning piece of architecture and a testimony to the sheer talent and wisdom of the Chalukyan architects and sculptors. The walls depict a story from a mythology or a scene from a daily life in 8th century. An absolutely must see.
There are a lot of monkeys in the vicinity, do not carry food items with you.

Its one of the UNESCOheritage site, its well maintained. Enough parking places available. Its recommended to visit during winter, as during summer the temperature may shoot high. Their are 4 caves caved out of the red stones, looks beautiful. A must visit.

Fascinating dive into the history of Dravidian architecture and beginning of cave temples in southern India.
The carvings on the caves are breathtaking and very ornate.
Only 4 caves are open to public and can be covered in 30 mins or so.
Please wear walking shoes as they're are steps to be climbed and best time to visit is between 9-11am when the sun is shinning on the caves.

Must visit spot at Badami. Place is well maintained. The view of Badami town from the top is beautiful. To reach here you can either take an auto from the bus stand area or walk. Washroom facilities & parking space available.

Beautiful place, the carvings are fascinating and very ornate. There are four caves and you can cover them in 1-2 hours. There is Bhootnath Temple, Agastya Lake, archeological museum and few more ancient temples nearby in walking distance which you can explore after the caves. I'd recommend to visit only on weekdays if you really want to explore the place.

Mother Goddess Banashankari temple is a pilgrimage center for Hindus. It is situated at Cholachagudda near Badami of Bagalkot district in the state of Karnataka in India. The deity is commonly known as Banashankari or Vanashankari as. She is so named because the temple is in the midst of Tilakaaranya forest. The other widespread name of the deity is Shakambhari (ಶಖಮಬ್ರಿoroeor/ಶಾಕಂಬರಿ). She is an incarnation of the goddess Parvati who is the consort of Lord Shiva as well as His half body (Ardangi). Large number of devotees of Karnataka, Maharashtra and other places do visit this shrine frequently as the deity is believed to be very powerful goddess who grants the boons as prayed for by Her devotees. It is going on so for centuries.
The Kalyani Chalukya kings worshipped goddess Banashankari as their family deity and they constructed the temple during the 7th century. In the 18th century the existing structure was built by Maratha rulers. As in any other place the annual festivities do take place in this temple also by way of Jathra Mahotsava in the months of January or February. There will be cultural programmes, boat festival and Rathayatra in which the uthsavamurthy of the deity will be taken in procession on the ratha (chariot) and paraded around the city.
Bana is vana means forest; Shankari means the consort of Lord Shankara or Shiva that is Parvathi. Thus this temple is popularly called Vanashankari as it is in the center of Tilakaaranya forest. Yet another familiar name of this goddess is Shakambari means “Goddess of vegetable ". It is a combination of two Sanskrit words ‘Shaka’ and ‘Ambari’ meaning thereby the vegetables or vegetarian food and Ambari means "one who wears or put up with vegetables".
The natives have been using several other names in the slangish way such as Balavva, Banadavva, Sunkavva, Shiravanthi, Chowdamma, Vanadurge and so on. The goddess Banashankari was the Kuladevi (royal family deity) of the Chalukya rulers. At present some of the Deshastha Brahmins and Devangas (weaver community persons) have been worshipping Her with great reverence as their Kuladevatha.

But seeing the idol in the Sanctum Sanctorium is mesmerising and will give you an electrifying positice energy.

Banashankari Amma temple, is located at Cholachagudd near Badami in Bagalkot district Karnataka
The temple is popularly called Shakambhari ಶಾಕoಭರಿ Or Banashankari Vanashankari' since it is located in the Tilakaaranya forest.
The temple attracts devotees from Karnataka as well as the neighbouring state of Maharashtra. The original temple was built by the 7th century Badami Chalukya kings, who worshipped goddess Banashankari as their tutelary deity.

The goddess appeared through the fire of the Yagna (fire-sacrifice) in the form of the goddess Shakambari. She then killed the demon after a fierce encounter and restored peace in the region. Banashankari is considered as the incarnation of goddess Parvati, who is the consort of god Shiva.

At a distance of 5 Kms from Badami, Banashankari Temple is located at Cholachagudda. Dedicated to Banashankari Devi, an incarnation of Goddess Parvati, it's one of the famous temples in the district.

Dress Code : Modest clothing with arms and legs covered. Sheer clothing is prohibited as well.

The Abhisheka is held from 6:30 AM to 8:30 AM, everyday. The Banashankari Temple... timings for Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Sunday is from 6:00 AM to 1:00 PM and 4:30 PM to 8:00 PM. The Badami Banashankari Temple pooja timings for Tuesday are from 6:00 AM to 1:00 PM and 3:00 PM to 9:00 PM.

The Banashankari Amma Temple was originally built by the Chalukyas during the 7th century. The Goddess Banashankari was their family deity. According to an inscription, this image of the Banashankari Amma was installed by Jagadekamalla I in 630 AD. This temple was later renovated by the Marathas in the 18th century.

Built in early decades of 600 CE , this awesome temple is one of the oldest surviving structural stone temples of South India . It is situated in the highest summit of the Northern Hill of Badami . Access is through the Fort gate , via steps that lead through stunningly beautiful vistas . It is an exhilerating trek of 30 to 40 minutes ( one way) but will worth the effort . Both the temple and the view of the countryside all around are memorable .
The sanctum of the temple is now empty . The outer walls are ornamented with narrative panels illustrating events from Ramayana and Krishna Leela . Inspite of being  weather  worn ,the friezes are exquisite .

Deep in the rocky mountains of Bagalkot district in northern Karnataka, lies an architectural wonder. The tiny town of Badami in Bagalkot district is home to the rock-cut Badami Caves, a complex of Hindu and Jain cave temples. The cave temples in Badami are remnants of the Chalukya dynasty.
